title: 114_s2598
content: The Act may be cited as the "Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame Commemorative Coin Act". The Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame was founded in 1959 in Springfield, Massachusetts to honor the creator of basketball, Dr. James Naismith. It recognizes players, coaches, referees, and contributors to the sport. The Inaugural Hall of Fame Class of 1959 included 17 honorees, with Dr. James Naismith among them. The Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame, founded in 1959 in Springfield, Massachusetts, honors basketball's creator, Dr. James Naismith, and recognizes players, coaches, referees, and contributors. Inductees include George Mikan, Forrest C. Allen, Angelo Luisetti, the Original Celtics, and the First Team. The Hall of Fame is renowned worldwide for preserving basketball history and celebrating the sport's greatest figures. It offers educational programs promoting positive values demonstrated by basketball legends. Basketball is considered a national treasure in the United States for its fast-paced nature reflecting freedom. The Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame, established in 1959 in Springfield, Massachusetts, is home to the largest collection of basketball memorabilia in the world. It welcomes over 6,000,000 visitors interested in the rich history of the game and reaches over 7,000,000 Americans through educational programs, events, and its interactive website. The Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame offers customized educational programs using basketball to teach various topics like financial literacy, mathematics, civil rights, leadership, and history. They will lead the celebration of basketball's 60th anniversary in partnership with NBA, NCAA, and USA Basketball during the 2019-2020 season. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and metal compositions. The coins minted under this Act will have a diameter of 1.205 inches and be minted to the specifications for half-dollar coins. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items, with a dome shape. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design for coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. Each coin will have a value designation, the year "2019" inscribed, and include words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The Secretary will hold a competition to determine the design of the common obverse of the coins, emblematic of basketball. The Secretary will select and approve design proposals for coins minted under this Act, encouraging 3-dimensional models. Proposals can be submitted by artists, engravers, government employees, and the general public. The winning design will receive compensation of at least $5,000. The design on the common reverse of the coins minted under this Act will depict a basketball. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2019. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act will include surcharges: $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $5 for the half-dollar coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame to fund operations. The Hall of Fame will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge may exceed the specified amounts. (d) Limitation.--No surcharge may be included for any coin issued under this Act during a calendar year if it would exceed the annual commemorative coin program issuance limitation. The Secretary of the Treasury can provide guidance on this.
